articles.headline: Hurry Up and Credit My Account
articles.snippet: In a digital age, banks still operate under old laws on how quickly they credit accounts when consumers make deposits. Can procedures be speeded up?
articles.abstract: In a digital age, banks still operate under old laws on how quickly they credit accounts when consumers make deposits. Can procedures be speeded up?
articles.lead_paragraph: What is it with these banks that are so quick to hit you with a fee for spending more than you have in your checking account but take their own sweet time in crediting deposits?

articles.headline: Russia’s Reaction on Missile Plan Leaves Iran Issue Hanging
articles.snippet: Russian leaders hailed President Obama’s antimissile decision, but did not offer any immediate signal of concessions, especially on Iran.
articles.abstract: Russian leaders hailed President Obama’s antimissile decision, but did not offer any immediate signal of concessions, especially on Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  President Obama’s decision to cancel an antimissile defense system in Eastern Europe earned a strong welcome from Russian leaders on Friday. Now, the question is whether Russia will do more to help prevent Iran from developing nuclear weapons.
articles.byline: By Clifford J. Levy and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Vivendi’s Stake in NBC Universal May Be Sold
articles.snippet: Vivendi’s 20 percent stake in the company could be worth $7 billion, analysts say.
articles.abstract: Vivendi’s 20 percent stake in the company could be worth $7 billion, analysts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at General Electric say they believe that Vivendi, the French conglomerate, will exercise its right later this year to sell its stake in NBC Universal, a move that could lead to NBC Universal’s being spun off into a separate public company in 2010, according to people briefed on the matter who spoke anonymously in order to discuss internal deliberations.

articles.headline: The Bailout Bill Comes Due, Vexing Agencies
articles.snippet: The bill is starting to come due for the measures instituted by federal regulators to prevent the collapse of the financial system.
articles.abstract: The bill is starting to come due for the measures instituted by federal regulators to prevent the collapse of the financial system.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, as the financial system was threatening to collapse, federal regulators offered all sorts of assistance to ward off catastrophe. The strategy worked, at least so far, but the bill is starting to come due.

articles.headline: Film Chief at Disney Steps Down
articles.snippet: The chairman of Walt Disney Studios, Dick Cook, announced his resignation late Friday as the division he has led struggled with profitability in a shifting media landscape.
articles.abstract: The chairman of Walt Disney Studios, Dick Cook, announced his resignation late Friday as the division he has led struggled with profitability in a shifting media landscape.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  The chairman of Walt Disney Studios, Dick Cook, resigned late Friday following struggles with profitability, creative focus and a shifting relationship with other Disney units.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Free Speech Battle Arises From Dog Fighting Videos
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court is being asked to rule that a category of expression deserves no First Amendment protection.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court is being asked to rule that a category of expression deserves no First Amendment protection.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The next great First Amendment battle in the Supreme Court concerns, of all things, dogfight videos.

articles.headline: Recession Drives Women Back to the Work Force
articles.snippet: Many highly educated women who had left work to stay at home with their children are rejoining the labor pool.
articles.abstract: Many highly educated women who had left work to stay at home with their children are rejoining the labor pool.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Great Recession is pushing many highly educated women who had left work to stay at home with their children to dive back into the labor pool, according to several nationally recognized experts on women in the workplace.

articles.headline: Plugged-In Age Feeds a Hunger for Electricity
articles.snippet: Electronic devices are the fastest-growing source of power demand in the world, but there is resistance to efficiency.
articles.abstract: Electronic devices are the fastest-growing source of power demand in the world, but there is resistance to efficiency.
articles.lead_paragraph: With two laptop-loving children and a Jack Russell terrier hemmed in by an electric fence, Peter Troast figured his household used a lot of power. Just how much did not really hit him until the night the family turned off the overhead lights at their home in Maine and began hunting gadgets that glowed in the dark.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Kate Galbraith

articles.headline: For Edwards, Drama Builds Toward a Denouement
articles.snippet: Facing an investigation, John Edwards is considering declaring that he is the father of another woman’s child, associates said.
articles.abstract: Facing an investigation, John Edwards is considering declaring that he is the father of another woman’s child, associates said.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C.  The story of the spectacular rise and fall of John Edwards, with its sordid can’t-look-away dimensions, is moving slowly but deliberately to its conclusion here in North Carolina.

articles.headline: Leading Senator Pushes New Plan to Oversee Banks
articles.snippet: The head of the Senate Banking Committee will propose the merger of four bank agencies into one super-regulator.
articles.abstract: The head of the Senate Banking Committee will propose the merger of four bank agencies into one super-regulator.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The senior Senate Democrat shepherding legislation to overhaul the nation’s financial system is planning to propose the merger of four bank agencies into one super-regulator, an idea that is significantly different from what President Obama envisions.

articles.headline: Detroit’s Mr. Fix-It Takes On Saturn
articles.snippet: Roger Penske sees the troubled brand as a potential jewel to be plucked from the scrap heap of G.M.’s bankruptcy.
articles.abstract: Roger Penske sees the troubled brand as a potential jewel to be plucked from the scrap heap of G.M.’s bankruptcy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: Too Many ‘No’ Votes to Be Ignored
articles.snippet: It seems that the financial fiasco of the last few years and the lax oversight at major banks are encouraging investors to vote against board members.
articles.abstract: It seems that the financial fiasco of the last few years and the lax oversight at major banks are encouraging investors to vote against board members.
articles.lead_paragraph: ARE the days of the cocooned corporate director finally coming to an end? One can only hope. Even though directors  through the boards they sit on and the various committees they oversee  are supposed to keep wayward or incompetent chief executives at bay, all too often they are, in practice, just cronies of management.

articles.headline: Belatedly, Egypt Spots Flaws in Wiping Out Pigs
articles.snippet: When the government killed the pigs in Egypt in an attempt to combat swine flu, it was warned that Cairo would be overwhelmed with trash. Now, it is.
articles.abstract: When the government killed the pigs in Egypt in an attempt to combat swine flu, it was warned that Cairo would be overwhelmed with trash. Now, it is.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO  It is unlikely anyone has ever come to this city and commented on how clean the streets are. But this litter-strewn metropolis is now wrestling with a garbage problem so severe it has managed to incite its weary residents and command the attention of the president.

articles.headline: Eager Students Fall Prey to Apartheid’s Legacy
articles.snippet: Schools in South Africa are bursting with hopeful students, but the education system often fails those who most need it.
articles.abstract: Schools in South Africa are bursting with hopeful students, but the education system often fails those who most need it.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHAYELITSHA, South Africa  Seniors here at Kwamfundo high school sang freedom songs and protested outside the staff room last year because their accounting teacher chronically failed to show up for class. With looming national examinations that would determine whether they were bound for a university or joblessness, they demanded a replacement.

articles.headline: Can Amazon Be the Wal-Mart of the Web?
articles.snippet: Amazon is expected to soon sell more general merchandise than media products like books and DVDs.
articles.abstract: Amazon is expected to soon sell more general merchandise than media products like books and DVDs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Phoenix

articles.headline: Patent Auctions Offer Protections to Inventors
articles.snippet: Instead of spending millions in protracted legal battles, some inventors are turning to firms that will auction their rights to the highest bidders.
articles.abstract: Instead of spending millions in protracted legal battles, some inventors are turning to firms that will auction their rights to the highest bidders.
articles.lead_paragraph: The world can be a rough place for independent inventors. They can often find themselves in court, battling big corporations, spending piles of money on lawyers and leaving it up to judges and juries to determine the value of their hard-won patents.

articles.headline: Investment in a City of Struggles
articles.snippet: Reporters from Time Inc.’s magazines and Web sites are spending a year in Detroit — a city that’s been punished by the implosion of the auto industry, but that began failing many years before.
articles.abstract: Reporters from Time Inc.’s magazines and Web sites are spending a year in Detroit — a city that’s been punished by the implosion of the auto industry, but that began failing many years before.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT

articles.headline: Doubts Fade and Couric Is Energized
articles.snippet: With her contract expiring in 2011, Katie Couric is again fielding questions about what’s next, but now without suggestions of an early exit.
articles.abstract: With her contract expiring in 2011, Katie Couric is again fielding questions about what’s next, but now without suggestions of an early exit.
articles.lead_paragraph: For much of 2008, the TV cognoscenti assumed that Katie Couric would be anywhere but in the “CBS Evening News” anchor chair by now.

articles.headline: Disney Faces Rights Issues Over Marvel
articles.snippet: The legal notices expressed an intent by Jack Kirby’s heirs to regain copyrights to some of the superhero characters he created for Marvel.
articles.abstract: The legal notices expressed an intent by Jack Kirby’s heirs to regain copyrights to some of the superhero characters he created for Marvel.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  Walt Disney’s proposed $4 billion acquisition of Marvel Entertainment may come with a headache: newly filed claims challenging Marvel’s long-term rights to some of its superhero characters.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Once Slave to Luxury, Japan Catches Thrift Bug
articles.snippet: This recession has done something that earlier declines could not: turned the Japanese into Wal-Mart shoppers.
articles.abstract: This recession has done something that earlier declines could not: turned the Japanese into Wal-Mart shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Not long ago, many Japanese bought so many $100 melons and $1,000 handbags that this was the only country in the world where luxury products were considered mass market.

articles.headline: Terror Suspect Had Bomb Guide, Authorities Say
articles.snippet: A man arrested in Colorado had been trained in weapons and explosives in Pakistan, according to court papers.
articles.abstract: A man arrested in Colorado had been trained in weapons and explosives in Pakistan, according to court papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The central figure in what authorities describe as a widening inquiry into a possible plot to detonate explosives in the United States had been trained in weapons and explosives in Pakistan and, according to court papers released Sunday, had made nine pages of handwritten notes on how to make and handle bombs.
articles.byline: By David Johnston and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: For President, Five Programs, One Message
articles.snippet: The president’s talk-show grand slam was a remarkable — and remarkably overt — display of media management.
articles.abstract: The president’s talk-show grand slam was a remarkable — and remarkably overt — display of media management.
articles.lead_paragraph: No one shifted an armchair, moved a flower arrangement or asked an unexpected question.

articles.headline: Congress Presses for Details From Bank of America on Talks
articles.snippet: Bank of America is being told by a House Democrat that it cannot use attorney-client privilege to withhold legal conversations about acquiring Merrill Lynch.
articles.abstract: Bank of America is being told by a House Democrat that it cannot use attorney-client privilege to withhold legal conversations about acquiring Merrill Lynch.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  For months, Bank of America has been trying to keep secret its legal conversations at the end of last year about its coming merger with Merrill Lynch. So far, it has succeeded, mainly by arguing that those conversations should remain confidential because they are protected by attorney-client privilege.

articles.headline: General Calls for More U.S. Troops to Avoid Afghan Failure
articles.snippet: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal warned in a confidential assessment that he needed additional troops by next year or the conflict “will likely result in failure.”
articles.abstract: Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal warned in a confidential assessment that he needed additional troops by next year or the conflict “will likely result in failure.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The top military commander in Afghanistan warns in a confidential assessment of the war there that he needs additional troops within the next year or else the conflict “will likely result in failure.”
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Dell to Spend $3.9 Billion to Acquire Perot Systems
articles.snippet: Seeking to grow beyond its core personal computer business, Dell announced that it would acquire the information technology provider Perot Systems.
articles.abstract: Seeking to grow beyond its core personal computer business, Dell announced that it would acquire the information technology provider Perot Systems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dell, which has struggled with flagging sales of personal computers and servers during the downturn, has bought itself a piece of the federal government’s stimulus pie.
articles.byline: By Saul Hansell and Ashlee Vance
